papers.title: Off-Label Use of Janus Kinase Inhibitors in Inflammatory Cutaneous Diseases.
papers.abstract: Dysregulation of Janus kinase (JAK) pathways from uncontrolled cytokine signaling comprises the pathological basis for many complex inflammatory cutaneous disorders. Oral JAK inhibitors, upadacitinib, tofacitinib, and baricitinib targeting JAK 1 and JAK 1/3, respectively, are currently US Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved for several rheumatic conditions. However, studies have shown that JAK-mediated signaling pathways are involved in many immune-related dermatologic conditions. As a result, for recalcitrant diseases, JAK inhibitors are potential alternative therapies due to their broad targeted inhibitory mechanisms. In this case series, we present the successful off-label treatment of 6 cases across dermatomyositis, hidradenitis suppurativa, cutaneous lupus, and cutaneous Crohn’s disease, which failed conventional therapies with upadacitinib or tofacitinib. In the 3 dermatomyositis cases, use of upadacitinib or tofacitinib demonstrated positive clinical outcomes, with no recurrent symptoms in cases where upadacitinib was used. In treatment-resistant hidradenitis suppurativa, upadacitinib demonstrated reduced systemic flares and moderate cutaneous symptom improvement. In the case of cutaneous Crohn’s disease, upadacitinib resulted in reduced cutaneous symptoms without new flares. Tofacitinib resulted in completed resolution of cutaneous symptoms in our patient’s case of cutaneous lupus erythematosus. JAK inhibitors upadacitinib and tofacitinib may be potential drug candidates in patients with treatment-resistant disease, especially in cases of inflammatory cutaneous conditions such as dermatomyositis, hidradenitis suppurativa, cutaneous lupus, and cutaneous Crohn’s disease. Further studies with larger sample sizes among these conditions are warranted to assess potential broader applicability of the positive results demonstrated in our patient cases. J Drugs Dermatol. 2023;22(12):1183-1190. doi:10.36849/JDD.7500.

papers.title: JAK inhibitors in refractory dermatomyositis: A case series.
papers.abstract: This retrospective cohort study assessed the efficacy and safety of Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors, tofacitinib and baricitinib, in 14 patients with refractory dermatomyositis (DM), a multisystemic autoimmune disorder with limited therapeutic options. Results demonstrated a significant median decrease of 21 points and a 76% reduction in the Cutaneous Dermatomyositis Disease Area and Severity Index (CDASI) scores, along with a complete resolution of muscular symptoms in 64% of the patients. JAK inhibitors were effective in managing refractory DM across various subtypes with mild and manageable adverse events.

papers.title: Clinical experience and safety of Janus kinase inhibitors in giant cell arteritis: a retrospective case series from Sweden.
papers.abstract: The Janus kinase (JAK)-STAT signaling pathway is relevant in both Takayasu and giant cell arteritis (GCA), and the use of JAK inhibitors (JAKi) in arthritis, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel disease is nowadays common. Some evidence of the clinical efficacy of JAKi in GCA exists and a phase III randomized controlled trial (RCT) of upadacitinib is currently recruiting. In 2017, we started using barcitinib in a GCA patient with inadequate response to corticosteroids, and later on, we treated other 14 GCA patients with baricitinib/tofacitinib during intense follow-up. The retrospective data of these 15 individuals are here summarized. GCA was diagnosed based on the ACR criteria and/or imaging techniques combined with increased C-reactive protein (CRP) and/or erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) followed by a good initial response to corticosteroids. JAKi was initiated based on inflammatory activity, with increased CRP, presumably dependent on GCA with clinical symptoms, despite unsatisfying high doses of prednisolone. The mean age at JAKi initiation was 70.1 years and the mean exposure to JAKi was 19 months. From initiation, significant reductions in CRP were seen already at 3 (

papers.title: Baricitinib in polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis: report of six cases.
papers.abstract: The objective of this case series is to describe the efficacy and safety of baricitinib (BARI) in a group of patients with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) and/or giant cell arteritis (GCA). These patients were treated with BARI due to either a refractory disease course or the unavailability of tocilizumab because of the pandemic. A total of six patients (five females and one male, median age 64 years, range 50-83) were treated with BARI. Two of them had isolated PMR, two had PMR with associated large vessel (LV)-GCA, one had LV-GCA presenting as fever of unknown origin, and one had cranial-GCA. All patients reported improvement with BARI. At the time of starting BARI, patients were taking a median prednisone dose of 8.75 mg/day (range 0-25), and the four patients with PMR had a median PMR-activity score of 23.3 (indicating high disease activity), which decreased to 1.58 after 6 months of treatment with BARI. Two of them could stop glucocorticoids (GC) and continue BARI monotherapy. One patient suffered from pneumonia, and BARI was therefore stopped. No other adverse events attributable to BARI were detected. Our case series supports previous reports suggesting the efficacy of Janus kinase inhibitors as a GC-sparing strategy in PMR and GCA.

papers.title: Efficacy of oral JAK1 or JAK1/2 inhibitor for treating refractory pruritus in dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa: A retrospective case series.
papers.abstract: Refractory pruritus is the most distressing, disease-related symptom in patients with dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB), inducing an itch-scratch-blister cycle. Chronic inflammation is a hallmark of DEB, thus upregulation of inflammatory cytokines and Janus kinase (JAK) signaling may play a role in DEB-related pruritus. We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of DEB patients with refractory pruritus who were treated with either baricitinib, a JAK1/2 inhibitor, or upadacitinib, a selective JAK1 inhibitor. Patients received baricitinib (4 mg) or upadacitinib (15 mg) once a day for 2-32 weeks. A total of 12 DEB patients (six recessive DEB and six dominant DEB) were included in this study. The mean±SD baseline pruritus visual analog scale (VAS) score was 7.5 ± 1.7. Upadacitinib or baricitinib treatment resulted in a rapid and sustained decrease in itch. Four out of 12 patients (33.3%) and seven out of 10 patients (70%) showed a decrease of at least 3 points in the pruritus VAS score from baseline at weeks 2 and 4, respectively. The mean percentage changes from baseline in pruritus VAS scores at weeks 2 and 4 were -42.9% and -52.7%, respectively. Subgroup analysis showed greater reductions in the pruritus VAS score in the baricitinib group (n = 5) compared to the upadacitinib group (n = 7), and in patients with epidermolysis bullosa pruriginosa (n = 3) compared to other subtypes of DEB (n = 9); however, these differences did not reach statistical significance. Three out of 10 (33.3%) patients showed at least a 2-point reduction in pain intensity from baseline at week 4. Eight out of 12 patients (66.7%) also showed a reduction in the number of new blisters, which correlated with a reduction in the pruritus score. No patient discontinued treatment because of serious adverse events. Our results suggest that JAK1 or JAK1/2 inhibitors could be a promising treatment option for DEB-related pruritus. Long-term safety should be assessed in future studies.

papers.title: JAK inhibitors in refractory juvenile idiopathic arthritis-associated uveitis.
papers.abstract: To present our preliminary experience with JAK inhibitors in treating patients affected by juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) and associated uveitis. Case series. Four consecutive patients with long-term history of juvenile idiopathic arthritis and severe associated uveitis were included in the study. Indication for treatment with JAK inhibitors was uncontrolled arthritis and/or uveitis despite different treatments with conventional and biologic disease modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). While on treatment with JAK inhibitors, namely, baricitinib (three cases) and tofacitinib (one case), all our patients showed improvement of uveitis defined as a reduction of intraocular inflammation according to Standardized Uveitis Nomenclature criteria. However, we observed a different response to treatment between the uveitis and the articular disease, as the latter did not respond as favorably as the former. Overall, the treatment was well tolerated by all patients and no ocular discomfort, ocular side effects, or allergic reactions were registered. JAK inhibitors may provide a new valuable treatment option in the therapeutic armamentarium for patients affected with JIA-associated uveitis, particularly in those refractory cases that are not adequately responding to conventional or biologic DMARDs.Key Points• A subset of patients with JIA uveitis either remain unresponsive or experience loss of efficacy• JAK inhibitors may provide a new valuable treatment option in JIA patients with uveitis• The safety profile was good with no occurrence of systemic side effects.

papers.title: A Case Report of JAK Inhibitors Therapy for Adult-Onset Still's Disease with Persistent Pruritic Lesions.
papers.abstract: Adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD) is a recognized autoinflammatory disorder of unknown etiology. The standard initial management for AOSD includes conventional corticosteroids and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs. In cases that are resistant to these treatments, additional therapeutic options such as immunosuppressants, biologics, and other alternative treatments may be considered. Yet, a significant proportion of patients remain unresponsive to these therapeutic interventions. Herein, a case is reported involving a patient with AOSD who had persistent pruritic lesions that did not respond to conventional therapy, but were alleviated with Janus kinase inhibitors (JAKi), namely baricitinib and upadacitinib. The objective is to expand the number of refractory AOSD cases treated with JAKi in clinical practice. Another aim is to offer potentially effective therapeutic options for AOSD patients who experience persistent pruritus.

papers.title: Use of Baricitinib in a patient with treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum.
papers.abstract: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare inflammatory neutrophilic disorder with no uniformly effective therapy and limited high-level evidence. Common therapies include immunosuppressive and immunomodulating agents. There exist several case series using small molecules as treatment modalities. Here, we report a case of a 78-year-old female with a diagnosis of pyoderma gangrenosum and metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma of the ovary who was treated with Baricitinib 4 mg daily in combination with a tapering course of prednisone after failing other conventional therapies including systemic corticosteroids, colchicine, and intravenous immunoglobulin.

papers.title: Janus kinase inhibitors and their use in non-infectious orbital inflammatory disorders: new treatment possibilities? A case series.
papers.abstract: We present a patient with isolated autoimmune anterior scleritis and a patient with nonspecific orbital inflammation (NSOI). Both patients were treated with systemic corticosteroids during multiple recurrences, with the addition of various disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), including biologics, in the case of scleritis, resulting in complications and local adverse events. Both patients were subsequently effectively managed using Janus kinase inhibitors (JAK-i), specifically baricitinib and tofacitinib without relapses of inflammation during the follow-up of more than one year. Only a slight transient increase in liver enzymes was reported in a patient with scleritis and no serious side effects.

papers.abstract: This clinical case series describes our experience with the use of Janus kinase 1/2 inhibitor baricitinib in two patients suffering from refractory adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD) as well as in one case suffering from AOSD-like autoinflammatory disease in the context of myelodysplastic syndrome. All patients suffered from disease non-responsive to conventional Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) as well as biological therapies including interleukin (IL)-1 and IL-6 blockade, relying instead on high daily doses of prednisolone. papers.title: Assessment of Clinical Response to Janus Kinase Inhibition in Patients With Familial Chilblain Lupus and TREX1 Mutation.
papers.abstract: Familial chilblain lupus is a monogenic autosomal dominant form of cutaneous lupus erythematosus that in most cases is caused by mutations in the 3 prime repair exonuclease 1 (TREX1). Familial chilblain lupus presents in early childhood with cold-induced painful erythematous infiltrates leading to mutilation and is associated with systemic involvement illustrated by an elevated type I interferon (IFN) signature in the skin and blood. Effective treatment is currently not available.

papers.title: Rheumatological complaints in H syndrome: from inflammatory profiling to target treatment in a case study.
papers.abstract: H Syndrome is a rare genetic condition caused by biallelic pathogenic variants in the SLC29A3 gene. It is characterized by a wide range of clinical manifestations, many of which are related to the immune-rheumatological field. These include scleroderma-like skin changes, deforming arthritis, and enlarged lymph nodes. The condition also features cardiac and endocrine defects, as well as hearing loss, for which the immune pathogenesis appears less clear. Immunomodulatory medications have been shown to improve many symptoms in recent experiences.

papers.title: JAK inhibitor treatment for inborn errors of JAK/STAT signaling: An ESID/EBMT-IEWP retrospective study.
papers.abstract: Inborn errors of immunity (IEI) with dysregulated JAK/STAT signaling present with variable manifestations of immune dysregulation and infections. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is potentially curative, but initially reported outcomes were poor. JAK inhibitors (JAKi) offer a targeted treatment option that may be an alternative or bridge to HSCT. However, data on their current use, treatment efficacy and adverse events are limited.

source.title: Clinical experience and safety of Janus kinase inhibitors in giant cell arteritis: a retrospective case series from Sweden.

patient_population.description: 15 GCA patients (mean age 70.1 years, 60% female, all Caucasian) with inadequate response to corticosteroids

treatment.dose: baricitinib 3.86 mg daily (range 2-4 mg), tofacitinib 10 mg daily

efficacy.effect_size_description: Significant reductions in CRP and ESR with concurrent prednisolone dose reduction
efficacy.endpoint_result: Significant CRP reduction at 3 months (p=0.02) and 6 months (p=0.02)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: JAK inhibitors demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory effects with CRP and ESR reductions at 3 and 6 months. Therapeutic benefit was achieved in 73% of patients at 6 months with successful steroid sparing. No GCA relapses were observed during treatment.

safety.safety_summary: Two patients experienced serious infections but JAK inhibitor therapy was retained or reintroduced after recovery. No malignancy, gastrointestinal perforation, or significant laboratory abnormalities were observed. Three patients discontinued due to sustained remission.

extractions.key_findings: JAK inhibitors showed encouraging efficacy in steroid-refractory GCA with acceptable safety profile in this largest case series to date.

source.title: Case report: Effectiveness of Janus kinase inhibitors in the management of isolated noninfectious uveitis: a case series.

patient_population.description: 3 patients (1 female, 2 male) aged 28-59 years with refractory isolated noninfectious uveitis (2 with anterior and intermediate uveitis, 1 with posterior uveitis/ampiginous choroiditis)

efficacy.effect_size_description: Complete remission in all patients with visual acuity improvement from mean 0.4 to 0.6
efficacy.endpoint_result: all 3 patients achieved remission lasting >1 year
efficacy.efficacy_summary: All three patients with refractory isolated noninfectious uveitis achieved complete remission lasting more than 1 year after baricitinib treatment. Mean visual acuity improved from 0.4 to 0.6 with mean time to remission of 6.3 months.

safety.safety_summary: No serious adverse events were observed during the mean 31.6-month follow-up period. One patient experienced a slight temporary increase in liver transaminase levels.

extractions.key_findings: First report documenting successful use of baricitinib in isolated noninfectious uveitis with 100% remission rate and favorable safety profile.

source.title: A Case Report of JAK Inhibitors Therapy for Adult-Onset Still's Disease with Persistent Pruritic Lesions.

extractions.disease: Adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD) with persistent pruritic lesions

patient_population.description: 52-year-old woman with AOSD presenting with fever, rash, joint pain, and persistent pruritic lesions

treatment.dose: baricitinib 1 mg twice daily, then switched to upadacitinib 15 mg once daily

efficacy.time_to_response: notable reduction in pruritus after starting baricitinib, complete resolution after 1 month of upadacitinib
efficacy.effect_size_description: complete resolution of persistent pruritic lesions and significant steroid dose reduction
efficacy.primary_endpoint: reduction in persistent pruritus and skin lesions
efficacy.endpoint_result: complete resolution of pruritus and skin lesions
efficacy.efficacy_summary: JAK inhibitor therapy led to complete resolution of persistent pruritic lesions that were refractory to conventional treatment. The patient achieved sustained clinical improvement with significant reduction in methylprednisolone dose from 80 mg daily to 2 mg every 3 days.

discontinuation_reasons: slight renal dysfunction - switched from baricitinib to upadacitinib
safety.safety_summary: Treatment was generally well-tolerated with only minor renal function changes noted with baricitinib, prompting switch to upadacitinib. No significant adverse reactions occurred during 12 months of JAK inhibitor therapy.

extractions.key_findings: JAK inhibitors effectively treated refractory AOSD with persistent pruritic lesions and allowed significant steroid dose reduction with good safety profile.

source.title: Use of Baricitinib in a patient with treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum.

patient_population.description: 78-year-old female with treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum and metastatic high-grade serous carcinoma of the ovary

efficacy.duration_of_response: ulcer recurred 4 weeks after discontinuation for lower extremity, axilla and elbow ulcers remained healed at 13 weeks follow-up
efficacy.effect_size_description: complete resolution of 2/3 ulcers, significant size reduction in 1/3 ulcers
efficacy.endpoint_result: right lower extremity ulcer decreased in size, right axilla and right elbow ulcers resolved completely
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib 4 mg daily for 12 weeks led to complete resolution of ulcers on right axilla and right elbow, and decreased size of right lower extremity ulcer in treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum. However, the lower extremity ulcer recurred 4 weeks after discontinuation while axilla and elbow ulcers remained healed.

serious_adverse_events: methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus right knee native joint septic arthritis
discontinuation_reasons: patient and oncology team decision to resume paclitaxel for cancer treatment
safety.safety_summary: Patient developed septic arthritis after discontinuing baricitinib, though temporal relationship unclear. No other adverse events reported during 12 weeks of treatment.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib showed efficacy in treatment-resistant pyoderma gangrenosum but required ongoing therapy to maintain response in some lesions.

source.title: Mixed results with baricitinib in biological-resistant adult-onset Still's disease and undifferentiated systemic autoinflammatory disease.

extractions.disease: Adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD) and undifferentiated systemic autoinflammatory disease

patient_population.description: 3 patients (2 female, 1 male) with biological-resistant AOSD/AOSD-like disease; ages 29-58 years; one patient had concurrent myelodysplastic syndrome

efficacy.effect_size_description: Complete clinical and biochemical remission in responders with normalization of CRP and ESR
efficacy.endpoint_result: complete remission in 2/3 patients, no response in 1/3 patients
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib showed mixed results with 2 of 3 patients achieving complete clinical and biochemical remission. One patient (P1) achieved sustained remission on monotherapy for 15 months, while another (P3) maintained remission for 9 months.

safety.safety_summary: One patient developed Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia at 7 months, which was successfully treated and patient remained on prophylaxis. This represents the first reported case of PCP infection following baricitinib use.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib may be effective in biological-resistant AOSD, but opportunistic infections are a concern requiring careful monitoring.

source.title: Assessment of Clinical Response to Janus Kinase Inhibition in Patients With Familial Chilblain Lupus and TREX1 Mutation.

extractions.disease: Familial chilblain lupus with TREX1 mutation

patient_population.description: 2 women and 1 man; mean age 51 years (SD 24); all with TREX1 mutations causing familial chilblain lupus

efficacy.effect_size_description: Significant improvement in cutaneous lesions with suppression of systemic type I IFN activation
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Reduction of cutaneous lupus lesions measured by revised cutaneous lupus area and severity index (CLASI)
efficacy.endpoint_result: Significant improvement of cutaneous lupus lesions in all 3 patients
efficacy.efficacy_summary: All 3 patients showed significant improvement of cutaneous lupus lesions with suppression of systemic type I interferon activation. One patient achieved complete remission of pain, while 2 patients had partial reduction in joint inflammation-associated pain.

safety.safety_summary: No severe adverse reactions were reported during the 3-month treatment period. The treatment was well tolerated in all patients.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib demonstrated therapeutic efficacy in familial chilblain lupus, a monogenic form of lupus, with complete response in skin lesions and IFN signature suppression in all patients.

source.title: Rheumatological complaints in H syndrome: from inflammatory profiling to target treatment in a case study.

patient_population.description: 21-year-old female with H syndrome due to compound heterozygosity for SLC29A3 gene mutations, presenting with deforming arthritis, contractures, and interferon-mediated inflammation

efficacy.effect_size_description: dramatic improvement with complete normalization of inflammatory markers
efficacy.primary_endpoint: normalization of inflammatory markers (CRP, ESR, Interferon Score)
efficacy.endpoint_result: CRP decreased from 39.6 to 1.8 mg/L, ESR from 73 to 15 mm/h, Interferon Score from 22.3 to 1.4
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib alone provided only partial improvement, but combination with hydroxychloroquine led to dramatic symptom improvement and complete normalization of inflammatory markers. Patient showed substantial improvement in walking ability and complete range of motion in hips.

safety.safety_summary: No adverse events or safety concerns reported during the 12-month treatment period. Treatment was well tolerated.

extractions.key_findings: First report of JAK inhibitor use in H syndrome, with baricitinib plus hydroxychloroquine achieving complete normalization of interferon-mediated inflammation and significant clinical improvement in this rare genetic disorder.

source.title: Off-label use of Baricitinib improves moderate and severe atopic dermatitis in China through inhibiting MAPK and PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway via targeting JAK-STAT signaling of CD4

patient_population.description: adults with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis (mean age 51.2 years, 78.3% male) inadequately controlled by topical medications

efficacy.effect_size_description: significant improvement in clinical symptoms and immune hyperresponsiveness
efficacy.endpoint_result: significant reduction in EASI score from baseline 34.50 to post-treatment
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib significantly improved clinical symptoms in moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis patients, reducing EASI scores, vIGA scores, and Itch NRS scores. The treatment also normalized immune hyperresponsiveness and reduced Th2-mediated inflammation through inhibition of MAPK and PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathways.

safety.safety_summary: No significant safety issues were reported during the 4-week treatment period. The study mentions that JAK inhibitors are safe and effective with significantly reduced side effects compared to traditional immunosuppressants.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib effectively treated moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis through inhibition of JAK-STAT signaling and downstream MAPK and PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathways, reducing Th2-mediated inflammation with favorable safety profile.

source.title: Alopecia Areata Following the Use of Belimumab in a Patient with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and Arthritis Who Responded Well to Baricitinib: A Case Report.

extractions.disease: Systemic lupus erythematosus with alopecia areata/alopecia universalis and arthritis

patient_population.description: 54-year-old Saudi female with SLE, oligoarthritis, and progressive alopecia (areata to universalis)

treatment.duration: ongoing since treatment initiation (at least several months to March 2024)

efficacy.effect_size_description: near-complete hair regrowth and complete resolution of arthritis symptoms
efficacy.primary_endpoint: improvement in alopecia universalis and arthritis symptoms
efficacy.endpoint_result: significant improvement in alopecia universalis with nearly complete hair regrowth and resolution of joint symptoms
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib 4mg daily resulted in significant improvement in alopecia universalis with nearly complete hair regrowth within one month of treatment. Joint symptoms improved significantly with complete resolution of pain and tenderness, allowing for steroid tapering.

safety.safety_summary: No adverse events reported during baricitinib treatment. Patient was able to taper steroids completely and maintained remission.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib effectively treated both alopecia universalis and arthritis in SLE patient who failed multiple prior therapies including belimumab. Patient achieved sustained remission with negative anti-dsDNA serology.

source.title: JAK1/2 inhibition with baricitinib in the treatment of autoinflammatory interferonopathies.

extractions.disease: Autoinflammatory interferonopathies (CANDLE, SAVI, and other interferonopathies)

patient_population.description: 10 patients with CANDLE, 4 patients with SAVI, and 4 patients with other interferonopathies; mean age 12.5 years (range 1.2-24.1); 72% below 3rd percentile for height

treatment.dose: dose escalation to optimal tolerated doses

efficacy.duration_of_response: sustained improvement over mean 654.4 days in remission patients
efficacy.effect_size_description: 81% reduction in daily symptom scores; 75% reduction in corticosteroid doses
efficacy.endpoint_result: median daily symptom score decreased from 1.3 to 0.25 (P < 0.0001)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Significant improvements in daily symptom scores, corticosteroid dose reduction, and quality of life. Five CANDLE patients achieved lasting clinical remission with normal biomarkers. IFN biomarkers and inflammatory markers significantly decreased.

safety.safety_summary: Most common adverse events were upper respiratory infections and gastroenteritis. Three patients discontinued treatment, one due to serious BK viremia and azotemia. Overall safety profile was manageable with appropriate monitoring.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib effectively treated monogenic interferonopathies by reducing IFN signaling and inflammatory manifestations. Clinical remission achieved in 50% of CANDLE patients with sustained responses.

source.title: Disease flares with baricitinib dose reductions and development of flare criteria in patients with CANDLE/PRAAS.

extractions.disease: CANDLE/PRAAS (Chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatosis with lipodystrophy and elevated temperature/proteasome-associated autoinflammatory syndrome)

patient_population.description: Patients with genetically confirmed CANDLE/PRAAS, mean age 11.5 years (range 2.3-19.6)

treatment.dose: Higher exposures than used in rheumatoid arthritis, doses reduced 14 times in 9 patients

efficacy.time_to_response: Mean time to establish clinically effective dose was 1.06 years
efficacy.duration_of_response: Lasting clinical remission achieved in responders
efficacy.effect_size_description: 50% achieved lasting clinical remission with normalization of interferon response gene signature
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Disease flare development with dose reduction
efficacy.endpoint_result: 7/14 (50%) dose reductions resulted in disease flares, all 4 dose reductions >25% triggered flares
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib demonstrated efficacy in CANDLE/PRAAS with 50% of patients achieving lasting clinical remission. However, dose reductions frequently triggered disease flares, particularly with reductions >25%.

safety.safety_summary: Higher baricitinib exposures required for CANDLE/PRAAS led to BK viral complications and cytopenias requiring close monitoring. One patient discontinued due to presumed BK nephropathy.

extractions.follow_up_duration: Study period from October 2011 through December 2020
extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib shows efficacy in CANDLE/PRAAS but requires higher doses than RA, leading to increased safety risks including BK viral complications.

source.title: Sustained Interferon Signature Suppression With Anifrolumab in a Patient With STING-Associated Vasculopathy with Onset in Infancy Refractory to JAK Inhibitor and Dazukibart Therapy.

extractions.disease: STING-Associated Vasculopathy with Onset in Infancy (SAVI)

patient_population.description: 22-year-old patient with SAVI and de novo STING1 p.(Asn154Ser) mutation, with recurrent vasculitis ulcers, progressive osteolysis, and systemic inflammation

treatment.duration: over 10 years total, including combination therapy period

efficacy.effect_size_description: Partial efficacy - improved control compared to baricitinib alone but insufficient for sustained remission
efficacy.primary_endpoint: IFN I score suppression and vasculitic lesion healing
efficacy.endpoint_result: Partial response - combination of baricitinib and tocilizumab was partially effective but ultimately insufficient
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib monotherapy over 10+ years provided insufficient control of IFN I signaling and vasculitic lesions. Combination with tocilizumab showed partial effectiveness but ultimately failed to achieve sustained suppression, requiring transition to anifrolumab-based therapy.

safety.safety_summary: Baricitinib was associated with expected JAK inhibitor-related side effects including viral reactivations (BK virus, EBV) and opportunistic infections (molluscum contagiosum). These resolved after discontinuation and transition to anifrolumab.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib provided partial but insufficient control of SAVI symptoms, demonstrating the limitations of JAK inhibition in this rare interferonopathy and the need for alternative therapeutic approaches.

source.title: Pharmacokinetics, Pharmacodynamics, and Proposed Dosing of the Oral JAK1 and JAK2 Inhibitor Baricitinib in Pediatric and Young Adult CANDLE and SAVI Patients.

patient_population.description: pediatric and young adult patients with CANDLE and SAVI enrolled in compassionate use program

treatment.dose: 0.1 to 17 mg per day, up to 4 times daily

efficacy.effect_size_description: dose-dependent decreases in IFN biomarkers with mean AUC 1.83-fold higher than adult RA patients
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib demonstrated dose-dependent decreases in interferon biomarkers, confirming in vivo effect on type-1 IFN signaling in patients with Mendelian interferonopathies. The study established pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles supporting weight- and eGFR-based dosing regimens.

safety.safety_summary: No specific safety outcomes reported in this pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic study. Safety data not provided in the abstract.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib showed dose-dependent suppression of interferon signaling in rare interferonopathies, with pediatric patients requiring more frequent dosing due to shorter half-life.

source.title: Combination of Baricitinib and Phototherapy in Adults With Active Vitiligo: A Randomized Clinical Trial.

patient_population.description: adults with active and extensive vitiligo disease, the most severe form of vitiligo

efficacy.effect_size_description: 35.6 percentage point difference in VASI score improvement compared to placebo
efficacy.primary_endpoint: change in total Vitiligo Area Scoring Index (VASI) score
efficacy.endpoint_result: mean change of -44.8% for baricitinib group vs -9.2% for placebo group at week 36
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib combined with narrowband UV-B phototherapy demonstrated significant efficacy in treating severe active vitiligo. The treatment resulted in rapid and clinically meaningful repigmentation with a mean VASI score reduction of 44.8% compared to 9.2% with placebo.

safety.safety_summary: Safety outcomes were not detailed in the provided abstract. The study was described as evaluating both efficacy and tolerance of the combination treatment.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib combined with phototherapy provided rapid and clinically meaningful repigmentation in adults with severe, active vitiligo with significant reduction in disease activity.

source.title: Rapid response of lichen planus to baricitinib associated with suppression of cytotoxic CXCL13+CD8+ T cells.

patient_population.description: 12 patients with cutaneous lichen planus (mean age 63.6 years, 91.7% female, 75% White), with treatment-refractory disease and mean disease duration of 26.5 months

treatment.dose: 2 mg daily for 16 weeks, with optional dose escalation to 4 mg daily for additional 12 weeks
treatment.duration: 16 weeks (with optional 12-week extension at higher dose)

efficacy.time_to_response: As early as week 1 in 37.5% of patients, 100% by week 12
efficacy.duration_of_response: Response sustained at week 20 (4 weeks off therapy)
efficacy.effect_size_description: Large effect with 83.3% response rate, significant improvements in lesion count, body surface area, pruritus, and quality of life measures
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Treatment response defined as physician global assessment (PGA) scores of 0-3 with ≥50% score reduction
efficacy.endpoint_result: 10 of 12 patients (83.3%) achieved treatment response at week 16
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib demonstrated rapid and sustained efficacy in cutaneous lichen planus with 83.3% of patients achieving treatment response by week 16. Significant improvements were observed in total body lesion count, affected body surface area, pruritus scores, and quality of life measures. Response was sustained 4 weeks after treatment discontinuation.

safety.safety_summary: Treatment was well-tolerated with 12 total adverse events, mostly mild or moderate. Only one mild adverse event (neutropenia) was considered probably related to study drug. No adverse events led to treatment discontinuation.

extractions.key_findings: JAK inhibition with baricitinib effectively treated refractory cutaneous lichen planus through suppression of IFN-γ signature and cytotoxic CXCL13+CD8+ T cells, with molecular changes evident within 2 weeks of treatment.

source.title: Efficacy and safety of baricitinib in Japanese patients with autoinflammatory type I interferonopathies (NNS/CANDLE, SAVI, And AGS).

extractions.disease: Autoinflammatory type I interferonopathies (NNS/CANDLE, SAVI, and AGS)

patient_population.description: Japanese patients (5 with NNS/CANDLE, 3 with SAVI, 1 with AGS); 55.6% female, mean age 26 years, mean corticosteroid use 0.2 mg/kg

treatment.dose: Weight- and eGFR-based dosing with dose escalation during 8-week adjustment period

efficacy.time_to_response: Primary treatment period (12-24 weeks depending on condition)
efficacy.effect_size_description: Modest improvement in symptom scores for NNS/CANDLE and SAVI; minimal change in AGS
efficacy.primary_endpoint: Change in mean daily diary score (DDS) from baseline to end of primary treatment period
efficacy.endpoint_result: DDS decreased in NNS/CANDLE (0.22) and SAVI (0.21) patients; increased in AGS patient (0.07)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib showed clinical benefit in patients with NNS/CANDLE and SAVI with decreased symptom scores and reduced corticosteroid use. The single AGS patient showed minimal improvement in symptom scores.

safety.safety_summary: All patients experienced at least one adverse event. Three patients had serious adverse events, with one treatment-related SAE and one death from intracranial hemorrhage (not drug-related). BK polyomavirus detection was the most common AE.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib demonstrated potential therapeutic benefit for rare autoinflammatory interferonopathies, particularly NNS/CANDLE and SAVI, with acceptable safety profile in this vulnerable population.

source.title: Baricitinib for refractory Takayasu arteritis: a prospective cohort study in a tertiary referral centre.

patient_population.description: 10 patients with refractory TAK, median age 28 years, 9 female/1 male, median disease duration 50 months

efficacy.duration_of_response: 4/10 (40%) patients maintained overall treatment response during follow-up
efficacy.effect_size_description: 60% response rate at 6 months, 40% sustained response during extended follow-up
efficacy.primary_endpoint: overall treatment response rate at 6 months
efficacy.endpoint_result: 6/10 (60%) patients had overall treatment response at 6 months
efficacy.efficacy_summary: Baricitinib 4 mg daily achieved overall treatment response in 60% of patients with refractory TAK at 6 months. During extended follow-up, 40% maintained response and 80% were able to taper or maintain glucocorticoid doses.

safety.safety_summary: Baricitinib was well tolerated with only one patient (10%) discontinuing due to liver dysfunction. No other severe adverse events were reported during the study period.

extractions.key_findings: Baricitinib showed moderate efficacy in refractory Takayasu arteritis with 60% response rate and favorable safety profile. Two patients were able to discontinue glucocorticoids completely.

source.title: A retrospective study of the efficacy of JAK inhibitors or abatacept on rheumatoid arthritis-interstitial lung disease.

patient_population.description: RA-ILD patients, 69.3% women, mean age 59.9 years, mean disease duration 7.3 years, with ≥10% fibrosis on HRCT

treatment.dose: baricitinib 4 mg daily or tofacitinib 5 mg BID

efficacy.effect_size_description: Mean fibrosis rate decreased from 18.54% to 17.52% (not statistically significant, p=0.53)
efficacy.primary_endpoint: HRCT fibrosis progression assessed by computer-aided method
efficacy.endpoint_result: 83.9% of patients had stable or improved RA-ILD (64.5% stable, 19.4% improved, 16.1% worsened)
efficacy.efficacy_summary: JAK inhibitor treatment resulted in stability or improvement of RA-ILD in 83.9% of patients over 18 months. While mean fibrosis rates showed numerical improvement, this was not statistically significant.

safety.safety_summary: No specific safety data reported in this retrospective analysis focused on efficacy outcomes.

extractions.key_findings: JAK inhibitors showed comparable efficacy to abatacept in preventing RA-ILD progression, with disease duration being the only predictor of worsening in JAK-treated patients.

scored.disease: Adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD) with persistent pruritic lesions
Adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD) and undifferentiated systemic autoinflammatory disease
Familial chilblain lupus with TREX1 mutation
Systemic lupus erythematosus with alopecia areata/alopecia universalis and arthritis
Autoinflammatory interferonopathies (CANDLE, SAVI, and other interferonopathies)
CANDLE/PRAAS (Chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatosis with lipodystrophy and elevated temperature/proteasome-associated autoinflammatory syndrome)
STING-Associated Vasculopathy with Onset in Infancy (SAVI)
Autoinflammatory type I interferonopathies (NNS/CANDLE, SAVI, and AGS)
